statement:
For the derivative, the product rule $$(fg)' = f'g + fg'$$ is known as
the *Leibniz rule*. Below are various ways it can be generalized.

### Higher derivatives {#higher-derivatives .unnumbered}

Let $f,g$ be real (or complex) functions defined on an open interval of
${\mathbb{R}}$. If $f$ and $g$ are $k$ times differentiable, then
$$(fg)^{(k)} = \sum_{r=0}^k {k \choose r} f^{(k-r)} g^{(r)}.$$

### Generalized Leibniz rule for more functions {#generalized-leibniz-rule-for-more-functions .unnumbered}

Let $f_1,\ldots,f_r$ be real (or complex) valued functions that are
defined on an open interval of $\mathbb{R}$. If $f_1,\ldots,f_r$ are $n$
times differentiable, then
$$\frac{d^n}{dt^n}\prod_{i=1}^rf_i(t) = \sum_{n_1+\cdots+n_r=n} {n \choose n_1,n_2,\ldots,n_r} \prod_{i=1}^r \frac{d^{n_i}}{dt^{n_i}}f_i(t).$$
where ${n \choose n_1,n_2,\ldots,n_r}$ is the multinomial coefficient.

### Leibniz rule for multi-indices {#leibniz-rule-for-multi-indices .unnumbered}

If $f,g:{\mathbb{R}}^n \to {\mathbb{R}}$ are smooth functions defined on
an open set of ${\mathbb{R}}^n$, and $j$ is a multi-index, then
$$\partial^j(fg) = \sum_{i\le j} {j \choose i} \partial^i(f)\, \partial^{j-i}(g),$$
where $i$ is a multi-index.
